bad.work: 'He Cast Him Into the Bottomless Pit, and Shut Him Up'

title.reg: 'He Cast Him Into the Bottomless Pit, and Shut Him Up'

titlestmt.title: "He Cast Him Into the Bottomless Pit, and Shut Him Up": electronic edition
titlestmt.sponsor: The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and the Library of Congress

filedesc.extent: 2 XML files approx. 9KB; 2 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 146KB to 3200KB
filedesc.publicationstmt: Chapel Hill: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; Carolina Digital Library and Archives March 2011
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of an electronic edition of thirty-three of Blake’s water color illustrations to the Bible. All take their subjects from the New Testament and have been added to the twenty Old Testament subjects published in March 2010 as “Illustrations to the Bible, c. 1780-1824,” under Drawings and Paintings, Water Color Drawings. This new group is presented in our Preview mode, one that provides all the features of the Archive except Image Search and Inote (which provides detailed descriptions of Blake’s images).
Blake executed most of these New Testament water colors c. 1800-05 for his patron Thomas Butts. The exceptions are The Whore of Babylon of 1809 and The Parable of the Wise and Foolish Virgins in the Yale Center for British Art, datable to c. 1825. The subjects range from the childhood of Jesus to his ascension, the later history of his parents and one of his major followers, St. Paul, and a group of eight designs based on the Book of Revelation. While the illustrations of the life of Christ are fairly conventional in their subjects, in part because of the long tradition of picturing almost every event in the Gospels, individual motifs recall designs in Blake’s illuminated books and thus offer a window on Blake’s visual interpretation of the Bible. The illustrations of Revelation complement Blake’s intense engagement with apocalyptic events and images in his own poetry.
The selection of fifty-three biblical water colors now available in the Archive will be supplemented in the future with early works, such as Abraham and Isaac , datable to c. 1780, and will continue through Blake’s final biblical water colors, such as Moses Placed in the Ark of the Bulrushes .
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objtitle.title: "He Cast Him Into the Bottomless Pit, and Shut Him Up"

objdescid.origination: Anonymous delineator. The inscriptions on the mount, available under Supplemental Views, are not by Blake. They could not have been written before 1846, the earliest known date for the production of the paper on which the inscriptions are written. The identity of the calligrapher who wrote the inscriptions is not known.

objinfo.objsize: 35.8 x 32.4 cm. The mount (the backing mat) measures 49.8 x 35.2 cm.
objinfo.leafsize: 35.8 x 32.4 cm. The mount (the backing mat) measures 49.8 x 35.2 cm.
objinfo.medium: pen and ink and water color The inscriptions on the mount (the backing mat) are in pencil.
objinfo.support: paper, probably wove The mount (the backing mat) is Turnbull's Crayon Board, a card-like paper.
objinfo.framelines: 1 The design is surrounded by a single pen and ink framing line contiguous with the edge of the image.

provenance.name: Fogg Art Museum
provenance.note: Commissioned and acquired from Blake by Thomas Butts, c. 1800; by inheritance in 1845 to Thomas Butts, Jr.; sold anonymously, Sotheby's, 26 June 1852, lot 155 (£1.5s. to "Fuller," probably a dealer); Hugh Andrew Johnstone Munro; his estate or heirs by 1864; sold Christie's, 24 April 1868, lot 499 (£2.10s. to "Kibble," probably a dealer); Marsden J. Perry by 1905; sold in 1908 to W. A. White; given by White to the Fogg Art Museum in 1915.

repository.institution: Fogg Art Museum, Harvard University Museums

desc.objtitle:
"He Cast Him Into the Bottomless Pit, and Shut Him Up",
Object 1 (Butlin 524)

objnote.p: Blake signed the work, lower left, with his monogram; see the textual transcription. The inscriptions on the mount above and below the design are not by Blake. These are available under Related Works in the Archive.

illustration.illusobjdesc: This water color illustrates Revelation 20:1-3: "I saw an angel come down from heaven, having the key of the bottomless pit and a great chain in his hand." At the center of the design is a male facing away and twisting to face left and down. This is the angel from the text. He appears to be partly clothed in a transparent cloth secured around his waist. He has short, curly hair and raises his arms at 45 degrees. Both arms are bent. His right leg is extended backward and to the left and is on tiptoe, and both legs are bent. In his right hand he is holding a large metal key. In his left hand he is holding a link of a large chain that wraps around a snake-like figure with a humanoid male head that floats or hovers in the center of the design. This is Satan. Satan has a tail and his body is lined with spiky fins and is covered with scales. His head faces right, up, and forward. He has short, curly hair and an open mouth and looks at the angel above him. In the bottom right corner of the design may be at least two human figures of indeterminable gender. The leftmost figure faces forward, left, and up. Its mouth is open and its arms may be behind its back. It may be lying down. The rightmost figure faces forward and left but may be looking to the right. Its one clearly pictured leg is bent and drawn up and its left arm is wrapped around this leg. In the bottom left corner of the design are at least four figures, pictured as heads with hair and perhaps one extended arm of the figure third from the right. Four birds soar above. In the top left corner of the design are at least three human figures of indeterminable gender, facing left, down, and slightly forward. The left arms of two of these figures are dangling. Above these figures are at least six flying birds, facing forward. The sky in the background is dark, suggesting that the scene may take place at night, but a pink wash toward the top left corner of the design may suggest sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: At the center of the design is a male facing away and twisting to face left and down. His face is in profile. This is the angel from the text. He appears to be partly clothed in a transparent cloth secured around his waist. He has short, curly hair and raises his arms at 45 degrees. Both arms are bent. His right leg is extended backward, to the right and is on tiptoe, and both legs are bent. In his right hand he is holding a large metal key. In his left hand he is holding a link of a large chain. He is looking at the figure below.

A snake- or eel-like figure with a humanoid male head floats or hovers in the center of the design. This is Satan. It has a tail and its body is lined with spiky fins and is covered with scales. His head faces right, up, and forward. He has short, curly hair and an open mouth and looks at the figure above.
A large chain wraps around a snake-like figure, and may be connected to a large metal key.

In the bottom right corner of the design may be at least two human figures of indeterminable gender. The leftmost figure faces forward, left, and up. Its mouth is open and its arms may be behind its back. It may be lying down.

In the bottom right corner of the design may be two figures of indeterminable gender. The rightmost figure faces forward and left but may be looking to the right. Its one pictured leg is bent and drawn up and its left arm is wrapped around this leg.

There are at least four figures lying prone and facing down in the bottom left corner of the design. We mainly see the tops of their heads, with long or curly hair. The figure third from the right extends his(?) left arm to the left. His head may be resting on his upper left arm.
In the bottom left corner of the design are at least four flying birds, facing forward.

In the top left corner of the design are at least three human figures of indeterminable gender, facing left, down, and slightly forward. Each figure's left arm dangles down. They may be floating or hovering.
In the top left corner of the design are at least six flying birds, facing forward.
The sky in the background is dark, suggesting that the scene may take place at night, but a pink wash in the top left corner of the design may suggest sunrise or sunset.

desc.objtitle:
"He Cast Him Into the Bottomless Pit, and Shut Him Up",
full view including mount inscriptions

objnote.p: Blake signed the work, lower left, with his monogram; see the textual transcription. The inscriptions on the mount (the backing mat) above and below the design are not by Blake.

"He Cast Him Into the Bottomless Pit, and Shut Him Up",
top mount inscription

objnote.p: The inscription on the mount (the backing mat) above the design is not by Blake.

lg.l: He cast him into the bottomless pit, & shut him up.

desc.objtitle:
"He Cast Him Into the Bottomless Pit, and Shut Him Up",
bottom mount inscriptions

objnote.p: The inscriptions on the mount (the backing mat) below the design are not by Blake.

lg.l: And I saw an angel come down from heaven, having the
key of the bottomless pit, & a great chain in his hand. And
he laid hold on the dragon, that old serpent, which is the
devil & Satan, and bound him a thousand years.
